description:
Curry is not part of traditional Chinese cuisine but appears in some popular Hong Kong dishes, mostly as curry sauce (curry fish balls, curry chicken and curry beef on rice) and as curry powder (Singapore-style noodles).

[咖喱](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%92%96%E5%96%B1) is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) (*ga lēi* in Cantonese, *kā li* in Mandarin) that sounds like *curry*.

[Hoisin sauce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoisin_sauce) is a dark, thick sauce made from soybeans and other flavors and spices.

**Characters**

{海鮮} means *seafood* ({海} is *ocean* and {鮮} is *fresh*, so *seafood* is literally *ocean fresh*). {醬} is *sauce*, so [海鮮醬](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B5%B7%E9%AE%AE%E9%86%AC) is *seafood sauce* (even though it doesn't contain seafood, so if you see a bottle labeled *vegan hoisin sauce*, well, obviously).

[XO sauce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XO_sauce) is a thick sauce containing dried seafood, ham, and flavorings such as chili peppers A 1980s Hong Kong invention, with rival claims as to which restaurant, XO sauce borrows its name from XO (extra old) [cognac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognac) (popular in Hong Kong), along with the pricing (over a hundred dollars for some jars, although you can pick it up for a more reasonable price at an Asian supermarket), and packaging (often in a fancy box).

**Characters**

{醬} is *sauce*.

Vinegar made from rice wine. Chinese rice vinegar comes in a variety of colors, or even clear, but red vinegar is often used as a dipping sauce.

**Characters**

{米} is *rice*, and {醋} is *vinegar*, so {米醋} is *rice vinegar*.
